dictionary.definition: [for someone’s words] to fill someone with eagerness or the desire to do something.  The speech fired the audience with enthusiasm for change. We were fired with anger to protest against the government.

to shoot at someone or something with a weapon. Someone fired a gun at my car! _ The cowboy fired at the rattlesnake.  The hunters fired away at the ducks. On television, somebody is always firing away at somebody else.

[of an internal combustion engine] having all its cylinders working and thus providing the maximum amount of power.  The old car is firing on all cylinders despite its age.  This thing’s not hitting on all cylinders.

dictionary.phrase: fish someone or something out of something

dictionary.phrase: fish something up out of something
dictionary.definition: to pull or hoist something out of something, especially after searching or reaching for it.  The old shopkeeper fished a huge pickle up out of the barrel.  He fished up a huge pickle.

dictionary.phrase: fit someone or something up† (with something)
dictionary.definition: to provide someone or something with something for a particular purpose. We fit the couple up with fins, masks, and snorkels for skin diving.  The clerk fitted up the couple with diving gear for their vacation.  She fit them with tanks and weights.

to insist on talking about something that no one is interested in, or that has already been thoroughly discussed. dictionary.phrase: For want of a nail the shoe was lost
dictionary.definition: Prov. Overlooking small details can have disastrous consequences. (You can quote any of the sentences in this proverb by themselves.) _Jill: I don’t think we need to check our bicycle tires before we go for our ride. Jane: I disagree. Cliché carefree; completely free and unhindered. (*Also: as ~.) _ Jane is always happy and free as a bird.  The convict escaped from jail and was as free as a bird for two days.  No, I’m not married. I don’t even have a girlfriend. I’m free as the air.

a translation or restatement that is not completely accurate and not well thought out; a translation or restatement done casually.  John gave a free translation of what our Japanese client asked for, and we missed the main issue. Anne gave a very free translation of the ancient Chinese poem.

just now having sold or used up the last of something.  Sorry, I can’t serve you scrambled eggs. We are fresh out of eggs. We are fresh out of nails. I sold the last box just ten minutes ago.  Lettuce? Sorry. I’m clean out.

to worry about someone or something. Please don’t fret about being a few minutes late. There is no need to fret over Larry.
to worry about someone or something. Please don’t fret about being a few minutes late. There is no need to fret over Larry.

dictionary.phrase: frighten one out of one’s wits
dictionary.definition: to frighten one very badly.  Oh! That loud noise scared me out of my wits.  I’ll give him a good scolding and frighten him out of his wits.  Oh, you frightened me out of a year’s growth! _ You frightened Bob out of his mind.

dictionary.phrase: frighten someone or an animal to death
dictionary.definition: to frighten a living creature badly enough to cause death. The roar of the plane engine seems to have frightened the little dog to death.

dictionary.phrase: scare someone or an animal to death
dictionary.definition: to frighten a living creature badly enough to cause death. The roar of the plane engine seems to have frightened the little dog to death.
to scare someone or something off.  The noise frightened the burglar away.  Something frightened away the prowlers. The high prices frightened the shoppers off.
to scare someone or something off.  The noise frightened the burglar away.  Something frightened away the prowlers. The high prices frightened the shoppers off.

dictionary.phrase: frighten the hell out of someone
dictionary.definition: to frighten someone badly, suddenly or both. (Use of hell and shit are crude.) _ These figures frighten the hell out of me.  The door blew shut and scared the shit out of me.  It takes a lot to scare the pants off a hardened criminal.

to frighten someone badly, suddenly or both. (Use of hell and shit are crude.) _ These figures frighten the hell out of me.  The door blew shut and scared the shit out of me.  It takes a lot to scare the pants off a hardened criminal.

frightened to the point of dying.  This poor animal has been frightened to death by the attacking dogs.

dictionary.phrase: from all corners of the world
dictionary.definition: from all places in the world.  People came from all corners of the world to attend the conference.

dictionary.phrase: from the four corners of the earth
dictionary.definition: from all places in the world.  People came from all corners of the world to attend the conference.

from all around, both close by and farther away. (In either order.) _ All the young people from far and near gathered at the high school for the game.  The eagles gathered from near and far at the river where the salmon were spawning.

from this point forward.  From here on in we do it my way.  I want everything clear from here on out.
from this point forward.  From here on in we do it my way.  I want everything clear from here on out.

in my own opinion. Mary: What do you think of all this? Tom: From my perspective, it is just terrible.  Bob: From my point of view, this looks like a very good deal. Bill: That’s good for you. I stand to lose money on it.  Alice: From where I stand, it appears that you’re going to have to pay a lot of money to get this matter settled. Sue: I’ll pay anything. I just want to get all this behind me.

holding attitudes or ideas that were popular and important in the past, but which are no longer considered relevant or in line with modern trends.  Grammar is not taught much now, but fortunately my son has a teacher from the old school.  Aunt Jane is from the old school. She never goes out without wearing a hat and gloves.

from today into the future.  We’ll live in love and peace from this day on.  I’ll treasure your gift from this day forward.

full of nonsense; talking nonsense.  Oh, shut up, Mary. You’re full of hot air.  Don’t pay any attention to Bill. He’s full of beans.  My English professor is full of bull.  You’re full of it.

always making mischief. Little Chuckie is sure full of the devil. Toward the end of the school year, the kids are always full of Old Nick.

to be very angry about someone or something.  She was just fuming over her broken vase.  She was still fuming about Larry the next morning.
to be very angry about someone or something.  She was just fuming over her broken vase.  She was still fuming about Larry the next morning.
a spot near the elbow bone that is very sensitive to the touch.  Ouch, I hit my funny bone.  Effie bumped her crazy bone and made a horrendous face.

dictionary.phrase: furnish something for someone or something
dictionary.definition: to provide something for someone or a group.  I would be happy to furnish dinner for the visitors. I furnished the board of directors with the information.

dictionary.phrase: furnish someone or something with something
dictionary.definition: to provide something for someone or a group.  I would be happy to furnish dinner for the visitors. I furnished the board of directors with the information.
to go about complaining; to move about in a busy manner.  Don’t fuss about so much. Things will take care of themselves. Now, stop fussing around and sit down.
to go about complaining; to move about in a busy manner.  Don’t fuss about so much. Things will take care of themselves. Now, stop fussing around and sit down.
to go from place to place, having fun.  I’m too old to gad around like that.  She wasted too much time gadding about with her friends.
to go from place to place, having fun.  I’m too old to gad around like that.  She wasted too much time gadding about with her friends.

The illegal activity has been found out or has come to an end.  When the police were waiting for them inside the bank vault, the would-be robbers knew that the game was up.  “The jig is up!” said the cop as he grabbed the shoulder of the pickpocket.

to take something in and store it; to harvest something in and store it. (Originally referred to grain stored in a granary.) _ Will they garner the crop in on time this year? _ They had garnered in the entire crop by late October.

to assemble or bring people into something or some place.  The hostess gathered the children into the house just as the storm hit. She gathered in the children. Harry gathered them in before the storm.

to interpret someone or something in very general terms.  Sometimes it isn’t wise to generalize about a complicated issue.  She is very complex and it is difficult to generalize on her.

people reaching puberty during the 1970s and 1980s. Three or four generation X’ers were in the antique store looking eagerly at some of those horrible old dinette chairs from the 1950s.

dictionary.phrase: get a charge out of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to receive special pleasure from someone or something. I really got a charge out of that comedian’s routine. Tom is really funny. I always get a kick out of his jokes. Bill really got a bang out of the present we gave him.

dictionary.phrase: get a bang out of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to receive special pleasure from someone or something. I really got a charge out of that comedian’s routine. Tom is really funny. I always get a kick out of his jokes. Bill really got a bang out of the present we gave him.

dictionary.phrase: get a kick out of someone or something

to start to hurry.  We are going to leave in five minutes, Jane. Get a hurry on! _ Mary! Get a move on! We can’t wait all day.
to start to hurry.  We are going to leave in five minutes, Jane. Get a hurry on! _ Mary! Get a move on! We can’t wait all day.
to make someone react, usually angrily.  Tease Joe about his girlfriend. That generally gets a rise from him.  I pestered Mary for half the afternoon, but didn’t get a rise out of her.

dictionary.phrase: get a rise out of someone
dictionary.definition: to make someone react, usually angrily.  Tease Joe about his girlfriend. That generally gets a rise from him.  I pestered Mary for half the afternoon, but didn’t get a rise out of her.

to manage to say something when other people are talking and ignoring you. (Often in the negative. Alludes to trying to “squeeze” a word into a running conversation.) _ It was such an exciting conversation that I could hardly get a word in edgewise.  Mary talks so fast that nobody can get a word in edgeways.

to manage to move around.  I broke my hip last year, but I can still get about.  Dad can’t get around too much anymore, so I go over to help him.

to be able to afford to live on very little money.  For the last two years, we have had to get along on a shoestring.  With so many expenses, it’s hard to get by on a shoestring.
to be able to afford to live on very little money.  For the last two years, we have had to get along on a shoestring.  With so many expenses, it’s hard to get by on a shoestring.
to do something and not get punished for it.  You can’t get away with that! _ Larry got by with the lie.
to do something and not get punished for it.  You can’t get away with that! _ Larry got by with the lie.

to begin to get serious; to begin to negotiate or conduct business.  All right, everyone. Let’s get down to business. There has been enough chitchat. When the president and vice president arrive, we can get down to business.

dictionary.phrase: get enough nerve up† (to do something)
dictionary.definition: to work up enough courage to do something.  I hope I can get enough nerve up to ask her for her autograph.  I wanted to do it, but I couldn’t get up enough nerve.  I thought he would never get up the courage to ask me for a date.

dictionary.phrase: get enough courage up† (to do something)
dictionary.definition: to work up enough courage to do something.  I hope I can get enough nerve up to ask her for her autograph.  I wanted to do it, but I couldn’t get up enough nerve.  I thought he would never get up the courage to ask me for a date.

dictionary.phrase: get enough guts up† (to do something)
dictionary.definition: to work up enough courage to do something.  I hope I can get enough nerve up to ask her for her autograph.  I wanted to do it, but I couldn’t get up enough nerve.  I thought he would never get up the courage to ask me for a date.

dictionary.definition: to work up enough courage to do something.  I hope I can get enough nerve up to ask her for her autograph.  I wanted to do it, but I couldn’t get up enough nerve.  I thought he would never get up the courage to ask me for a date.

dictionary.phrase: get free of someone or something
dictionary.definition: 1. to rid oneself of the burden of someone or something.  Can’t I get free of this problem? _ I can’t seem to get free of Randy. 2. to liberate oneself from someone or something.  I tried to get free of Mr. Franklin, but he kept talking and wouldn’t let me interrupt.  Is there any way that somebody can get free of Tom? _ I couldn’t get free of the nail that had snagged my sleeve.

dictionary.phrase: get free from someone or something
dictionary.definition: 1. to rid oneself of the burden of someone or something.  Can’t I get free of this problem? _ I can’t seem to get free of Randy. 2. to liberate oneself from someone or something.  I tried to get free of Mr. Franklin, but he kept talking and wouldn’t let me interrupt.  Is there any way that somebody can get free of Tom? _ I couldn’t get free of the nail that had snagged my sleeve.

dictionary.phrase: get into an argument (with someone) (about someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to enter a quarrel with someone about someone or something.  I don’t want to get into an argument with you about Dan. Mary got into an argument about money with Fred.  I really don’t want to get into an argument.

dictionary.phrase: get into an argument (with someone) (over someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to enter a quarrel with someone about someone or something.  I don’t want to get into an argument with you about Dan. Mary got into an argument about money with Fred.  I really don’t want to get into an argument.

Sl. to get up and get busy; to stop loafing and get to work. (Caution with ass. Butt is also offensive to some people.) _ Get off your ass and get busy! _ It’s time you got off your butt and started to work.

Sl. to get up and get busy; to stop loafing and get to work. (Caution with ass. Butt is also offensive to some people.) _ Get off your ass and get busy! _ It’s time you got off your butt and started to work.

Sl. to get up and get busy; to stop loafing and get to work. (Caution with ass. Butt is also offensive to some people.) _ Get off your ass and get busy! _ It’s time you got off your butt and started to work.
Inf. Leave someone alone!; Stop picking on someone! (Usually a command.) _ I’m tired of your criticism, Bill. Get off my case! _ Quit picking on her. Get off her back!
